newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turk police detain 24 in pro-Islamic school march.
newsitem.headline: Turk police detain 24 in pro-Islamic school march.

text.p: Police detained 24 Islamists in eastern Turkey on Friday as they took part in an unauthorised march to protest at an army-inspired closure plan for Islamic schools, state-run Anatolian news agency said.
After Friday prayers protesters marched from a mosque in the town of Bingol, chanting slogans in support of Turkey's religious Imam Hatip schools and Islamic sharia law.
"Do not touch my Imam Hatip", "Long live sharia", the agency reported them as chanting. It did not say how many protesters there were.
Scuffles broke out when police intervened to stop the march. One protester was injured in fighting as police tried to prevent another marcher from hurting himself with a knife, it said.
Islamist Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan on Thursday expressed support for Imam Hatip schools, saying that denying people access to religious schools amounted to a human rights abuse.
He was speaking in opposition to a plan demanded by the powerful army that compulsory education be increased to eight years in the same school from the current five.
This would effectively shut down the middle section of state religious schools, which now begin to take pupils at 11.
Turkey's secularists, particularly the military, believe the Imam Hatip schools are used as a breeding ground for activists in Erbakan's Welfare Party.
The eight-year education plan was among demands set out by the military-led National Security Council (NSC) in February.
Erbakan, also a member of the NSC, was a signatory to the council's list of demands, but he has been criticised since for not implementing any of them.
An association for Imam Hatip graduates said in a statement on Friday the group will hold a rally at an Istanbul square this weekend to protest the plan to close their schools.
